column11: Review Text

column8: Fabulous wood carvings, a real insider tip
column11: Embekka is the third temple, along with Lankathilaka and Gadeladheniya. "3 temple loop." It impresses with old, wonderful wood carvings in the access area to the shrine. Even the almost forgotten Sri Lankan martial art Angampora can be found here

column8: The wooden temple: 1 stage of the trek of the three temples.
column11: We independently did the "three temples" trek, with information from the Kandy Tourist Information Center, near the bus station, without problems. Embekka Devalaya was the first stop, not far from a bus stop coming from Kandy. The trek allows you to visit 3 temples built in different ages and materials. This dates back to the 1300s and many parts are in well-preserved wood. The most architecturally significant element is the Drummers' Hall, with wooden pillars that bring hundreds of beautiful carvings to the top and a very particular roof with beams tilted from above towards the visitor and fixed together in place by a giant pin, of which nothing equivalent can be found elsewhere. But the place itself is really beautiful, with a huge body tree and still quite unfrequented by tourists.  It was here that we discovered, with surprise and admiration, how a Buddhist temple in Sri Lanka can host Hindu deities.

A place near to the Kandy city where you can find AMAZING wood carvings. This Devalaya /Temple was built nearly 700 years ago and a very interesting place to visit in Sri Lanka. Many foreign tourists never miss out this location. This is a must visit place when you are travelling Kandy area. Yo can also visit Historical sites of Lanka thilaka Viharataya (Temple) and Gadaladeniya Viharaya (Temple) which located 4 km and 5.7 km respectively from here.

This is one of my favourite place. The temple was built by King Vikramabahu III, since 14th century, dedicated to Kataragama deviyo (a deity who is believed to be very powerful in Sri Lanka). There are 3 sections in this temple - Sanctum of Garagha, Dancing Hall & Drummer Hall which is the highlight of this place with intricate wood carvings. Entrance fee of LKR300 per person is well worth the penny for 30-45 mins visit especially anyone into wood carvings. We also saw group of students here for study excursion at this historical place. Visiting this temple can be combined with visits to Lankathilaka Temple & Temple of Galadenia where these Temples are within 30 mins drive to each other. Therefore, hiring driver service is necessary which we engaged “BLUE HAVEN TOURS” with superb driver named “Mr Sugath”.
The small wooden temple is a very interesting place and if you go early in the morning, you can enjoy it almost alone and have enough time to admire the different designs of each column, so unique!
In the grounds of the Royal Palace this historic arcaded structure has some magnificent old carved wooden columns.
This is a old Hindu temple. The carvings are excellent. A good temple to visit as part of the culture tour.
The devalaya was constructed in 14th century during the period of King Wickremabahu III.Most splendid wood carvings are found in Hevisi Mandapaya. Amazing place with splendid architecture.

column8: 14th century temple with impressive wood carvings
column11: A nice small temple with impressive woodwork. Its located in a peaceful village and it's well preserved. Great place to witness the creativity and imagination of ancient Sri Lankans. Getting there might be tricky because of winding country roads. If you are a foreign visitor, it'll cost 300Rs to enter.

column8: Word best wooden decorated carvings -  Ancient Sri Lanka.
column11: This temple located in very peaceful area suburb to Kandy. Every art loving people must visit this place at least one time. You can see world famous wooden carvings on there in various types of design. Special thing is the main hall was completely built in wood and also nails. Recommended for travelers to visit this place on your Sri Lanka travel.

A quiet peaceful temple a located  about 18 km from the city center. The temple is dedicated to god Katharagma. But the major attention goes to the Drummers' Hall popular as an amazing masterpiece Sri Lankan wooden architecture. Each pillar of the hall connecting to the high roof has ornate with wood carvings belongs to the 1371 AD. Its says, original building was three storied belong to the Gampola kingdom. However, what is seeing today is renovated in the Kandyan era. A less visited place by foreign and local travelers. May be due to the distance from city centre. It took about 45 minutes to reach the place.

Just amazing to see the exquisite wood carvings that came from the 14th century. They were so intricate. The main hall was completely constructed in wood...including the nails. There were some local school groups visiting  which made it even more fun.

This is a very historic and pretty temple set in peaceful countryside. The temple compound contains a cluster of well preserved old buildings with wonderful carved timbers, ornamental roofs etc. Entry cost is 300 rupees per person. We combined this with a visit to the nearby Lankatilake Temple. We took bus 644 from Kandy Goods Yard bus station to Lankatilake and returned on the 643 from Embekka. It is a 3 km walk between the two temples along a pretty country lane. The bus journeys are around an hour each way.
This is another ancient beautiful Buddhist and Hindu temple. A good temple to visit visit.You need about an hour here.
The best Wood Carvings in Gampola Era is found here .King Vikramabahu III built this place in worship of Kataragama deviyo.

Got here by bus from Kandy followed by short walk. People on bus told us best place to get off and showed walking route. Lovely peaceful old temple in a very small village.with brass and wood artisans working. Free toilets there.Sounds of drums gave atmosphere. Entry fee 300. Worth a visit if you have time and then walk to Lankatilake (about 50 minutes)

It was quite when we visited. May be because of May. But as soon as we arrived at the temple the official guardian of the temple came to us and greeted warmly. We were the only people at the temple that time. He took us to everywhere and showed most of the historic items. This place it about 25km away from kandy city. If you traveling with google maps you better select the route via Gelioya. Roads were good and the last end was under construction. But it was a comfortable ride. Car park was available and ticket was 50 per car. This temple and the dewalaya is very sacred and has many blessings. Specially if you wish to have baby, this is the place you should visit. Make sure you are completely cleansed yourself. I mean u need to be clean and if you had a funeral of your close relative then u have to wait for another 3 months before you visit. Pooja timings are in the picture I attached. Visit and make your dreams come true. !!!
Few days a go we went to Embekka Devalaya also Amazing due to unbelievable would carving, there have lot of lotus flower & ancient pictures

I don't know if this is worth a special visit but it is well worth getting a bus from Kandy to near Embekka and take a 8 km hike to visit 3 old temples. The temple is about 700 years old and is famous for the carvings on the columns that support the roof. While i was there , there was a large group of schoolchildren visiting this famous temple.

This is one of those smaller, off-the-beaten-track attractions which needs a visit if you're interested in history and archaeology. Being difficult to find means that it's not too busy (or at least wasn't when we were there), the Drumming Hall has dozens of ornate, skilfully carved and well-preserved wooden panels of wrestlers, a mermaid and much more.
A magnificent temple dating from the 1400s Brilliant wood carvings on the entrance porch A very well preserved bit of cultural heritage One of the three temples on the circuit near Kandy

Our drive had a real job finding this place. It’s pretty remote, but worth the trek. It’s a very small local temple with lovely carved wooden pillars. We went at dusk when the bats started hitting about  and an old man played the drums for evening worship as the sun set.

The devalaya (a.k.a Shrine) is situated within the cultural triangle and with around 30 minute drive from the Botanical Gardens of Peradeniya, Sri Lanka. This shrine was built during AD 1357 – 1374 by a King Vikramabahu to worship the god by the name of Katharagama Deviyo. The significance of this devalaya is the wooden carvings on the pillars and also on the roof. It is said that each of the carvings is unique and includes over 130 different variations. The wooden carvings denote the strength of the king’s army, the culture, religious beliefs and also the prestigious status of the kingdom. There are few routes to reach this location. Once is from Pilimathalawa in Colombo – Kandy road and the other once is from Gelioya in Kandy – Gampola road. The second road offers much view of paddy fields and villages than the first route. There are ample parking on the site and recommend to prepare with food and drinking water as sometimes it can be challenging to locate some of the essential needs in nearby places.

On the way to Kandy, we come across this architectural marvel of 14th century. This place has a big history behind. A Gampala period temple is now in a very sorry state. Though coming under the archaeological department  , the maintenance is is not worth mentioning. There are are guides to tell you all about the history. Different shrines for Karthikeya and Buddha and others are in place.The wooden carvings are real marvels.. There is a small entry fee . It looks like an old dilapidated temple in a tiny village.
Beautiful carvings. Spend time admiring the door as well with an interesting handle. We got there after sunset so can't really add much here as it was pretty dark and the lighting was poor.

Don’t miss this place if you want to see amazing wood carvings of breathtaking verity. Though the carvings are over 500 years old, they are amazingly preserved with the help of ancient preserving techniques. There are over 150 different carvings and each has its own back story. Don’t miss this place if you appreciate amazing craftsmanship blended with artistry.

In Sri Lanka is one of important place see some of wood carvings. Each caring on the wooden are with great meaning. Visitors should meet the people who tacking care of this place, they will let you know 100+ fantastic things about the carvings and the place. You will be amazed with meanings of the cravings. It will differ one to one.
We walked here from Lankatilaka temple in about one hour through villages and fields, very nice. The carvings at Embakke are superb and deserve a leisurely appreciation.
This is a place where you can see and study the amaizing arts of  wood carving in Sri Lankan society in Gampola era. Must visit place.
You will fi!nd the sign to Embekke half way between Kandy and Peradeniya. This is a wooden sanctuary that is unique in the country. Let the pictures speak for themselves!

This is not a "Temple" but a "Devalaya". It was constructed in Gampola (After Kandyan) Era. The roof structure is supported by wooden columns with exquisite wood carvings which are considered the best in Sri Lanka. There is a special pin like structure called "Madol Kurupawa" which is used to pin 16 beams of roof structure to a single point. Tickets are priced at 300 LKR for foreigners.
It's the wood workmanship at its best. You'll find a whole structure made out of wood without using a single nail.
Here you can find the best collection of wood carvings in Sri Lanka. There are many styles of ancient wood carvings.

This temple is very famous for carvings. I think this is the place I have visited where there are the nice and best carvings. I reached to this place from Kandy. I came via Colombo Kandy A1 road and then from Peradeniya I used google maps to find this place. It is not so far from Kandy. When you visit this place please take  time to watch carvings. Because you can see nice architectural work on roof too.

This is a nice small temple, not far from Kandy. Located using Google Maps. There is an old man at entrance who guided us for a small tip. When we arrived there was a religious ceremony taking place so we waited half an hour before we could see the whole temple. There are some unique wood carvings on the pillars of the temple. Also it is worth reading the history of the temple to appreciate it. It is completely different from the Budhist Temples you see in the Heritage Sites. Also there are 2 other temples nearby so it is worth travelling to this area. I appreciated the lack of crowds and huge entrance fees which you have to pay at other sites.

The drive to Embekka is interesting in itself, on smallish rural roads.  The wood carvings are exquisite, and amazingly well preserved considering that the temple has been exposed to the weather for hundreds of years.  If you are looking to escape the traffic surrounding Kandy Lake and the approaches to the city and can spare a couple of hours, this is a good option (combine with a trip to Lankatilake temple, which is nearby)
the wood carvings in this temple are very famous and they are considered great carvings. there's a guide in there so you can get to know alll the details of each and every carving there.
Very old shrine. The architecture is fabulous. All the pillars, rafters etc have detailed carvings. If you are in the area I would say it is worth while visiting

column7: Emirate of Sharjah, United Arab Emirates
column11: The Embekke Devalaya is one of the oldest places to visit in Kandy which was built on 1370's and it's a great place to learn about architecture, wall paintings and wood carvings.

This temple has a good number of different carvings. There was an uncle who was conducting the place. Make sure to get his help for get explanations of the carvings. Vehicles can be parked outside the temple.

Gadaladeniya, Lankatilaka and Embekke Devale Temples comprise the Three-Temples Loop about half hour's drive from Kandy. With transport (car or tuk-tuk) they can all be visited together in ~ 2 hours and are not particularly busy. We visited Dec 1st and the final road was closed due to a wash out - just have your driver park and you can walk in in about 15 minutes - very pretty through the rice fields. This shrine has richly carved wooden pillars which are beautiful. A pleasant old man may walk you around (un-necessarily) for a tip (he was sweet, not annoying). Take time to look at all the carvings - each panel is different.
This Devala is famous for wood carvings.. If you are teavelling along Kandy Nuwara eliya road it is only 4 km away from Gelioya town. Good place to visit for wood carving and history studies.
Embekka is one of the three places to visit from Colombo to Kandy journey. However, it is unclean and ridiculous ticket pricing for foreigners.
